This film is at most, haunting... poverty, despair and disillusionment surrounds the main protagonists: a Lebanese child, Zain (helmed by Zain Al Rafeea) and Ethiopian refugee, Rahil (helmed by Yordanos Shiferaw). Director, Nadine Labaki uses a documentary styled narrative, also showing an influence from Neo-Realism (Italian cinema) and Hunger Aesthetics (South American cinema).This films grounds its narrative within an interwoven situation of a displaced population in Beirut. There are many tenders moments between Zain with his siblings and newly-founded refugee Ethiopian family. Labiki's style reminds one of Brazilian Walter Salles approach with casting.This film is very powerful in giving the viewer the insight of a real situation on 21st century global migration, where macro economic devastation relies on human trafficking.

reviews.review_title: The most impressive child acting performance ever?
reviews.content: I've seen some incredible child acting performances over the years, most notably Leonardo DiCaprio in Gilbert Grape, Justin Henry in Kramer vs Kramer and Tatum O'Neal in Paper Moon. However, what Zain Al Rafeea achieves in this devastating movie is arguably on another level altogether. It should not be possible for a boy of 12 to be able to convey emotions in such a nuanced and delicate manner. It was genuinely astounding to witness. The fact that he was not a trained actor just makes it all the more incredible.Al Rafeea's brilliance is made possible by the phenomenal direction and writing of Nadine Labaki. Capharnaum is a truly heartbreaking piece of cinema that manages to convey the sheer horror of the subject matter without laying it on too thick or labouring it's point.

Without doubt the most heart-wrenching films of a generation. This is so real, this is happening all around the world. It is a film to make you think, make you cry and make you aware of the things you take for granted.5* acting
5* directing
5* writingCongratulations on a masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: A thought-provoking and gut-wrenching film that engrossed from beginning to end
reviews.content: The plot might suggest a depressing, uncomfortable film. Sure, but, despite the poverty, despite the cruelty, and despite the vulnerability of the young, the poor, and the dispossessed characters, 'Capernaum' is also an uplifting film, due entirely to the resilience, the courage, and the loving care shown by the film's remarkable young main character. A thought-provoking and gut-wrenching film that engrossed from beginning to end with Zain Al Rafeea gives one the best child performances ever.

reviews.review_title: Grim melodrama from an unfamiliar to me part of the world
reviews.content: This was so grim. Everything looks disgusting but it still has a message that their are worse places to live.We start with Zain a boy with no identification believed to be 12 years old in prison and attending a court case where he is trying to sue his parents for neglect.We flash hack to his squalid upbringing living in absolute filth in an overcrowded flat of some sort. He his closest to his sister who is then sold by his parents as a child bride. He did attempt to stop this and run off with his sister but he was too late. He then runs away from home.He meets a young Ethiopian Woman who is an illegal immigrant and has a baby son. She also live in squalor bur there is more love in this house.The Woman is arrested and put in prison for not having a work permit and now Zain is left to look after the baby not knowing what has happened to the mother.He is tricked into selling the baby.He then learns his sister has died and stabs the man who married her wounding him.A lot more happens and the detail is immense. You get a true feel for the living conditions.Zain has a good heart and does not put himself first when he is stuck with the baby.The end scene where Zain gets his identity is emotional.Having identification is something most humans with it take for granted and don't even think about it and this film really hits home how important having it is.A true Masterpiece and a must watch.

This didn't impress me much as I have seen Indian masterpieces such as Salaam Bombay and Page 3, which have whole sections of the films documented to showing the life of the juvenile delinquents.The acting is top notch. The fact that most of the actors are playing characters very close to their real life becomes apparent once you see how natural the performances are.I want to write a line about the IMDb summary. It literally describes the climactic moment of the film. Why would it ruin the build up is beyond me.It is good but shouldn't have been nominated for best foreign film. No wonder it lost out.

reviews.review_title: I hope more people will see this movie.
reviews.content: This subject ... this technique ... locked in the Oscar foreign language nomination. The performance of the little male master is too great! It took me a good couple of attempts to write something about this movie because i wanted to do it justice. The cinematography really amplifies the world these people live in, in a depressing but beautiful way.We follow a 12 year old Zain doing his best to survive in Lebanese slums.
Heartbreaking story of the slums of Beirut with outstanding performances from the two young lead. Can be a bit shorter.
All of the movie make me sad, and me crying, what the hell environment to grow up in. Hope no poor in the world, love and peace forever!

reviews.review_title: If you have a heart; this is for you

Thanks to director Nadine Labaki, who takes us on a tour to a parallel world which is way different from the one that we live in. Poverty is devastating, whichever shade it belongs, Capharnaüm takes us on a journey towards the worst shade of poverty that one gets to see. The story is seen through the eyes of a 12 year old boy, Zain living with his huge family in an impoverished neighbourhood in the suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon. Zain gives the audiences the world over, a sneak peek of a few days of his life in about a couple of hours. There is a parallel story of an illegal Ethiopian immigrant, Rahil and her cute little son Yonas, which merges with the story of Zain. Capharnaüm is a gentle reminder to ourselves to understand how much of a privileged life we are living. The character of Zain is an inspiration to all of us to fight for what we truly deserve in life. Innocence Lost is a crime too but who is responsible? The Society? The Government? The Corporates? The Corrupt? or the entire system?Fantastic work from director Nadine Labaki touches an emotional cord within us with such a moving story. Outstanding Cinematography was the main reason for Capharnaüm to have a soul on its own, ably supported by some very good editing to keep the liner story moving on beautifully. Production design, Costumes and make up team really must have worked hard enough to give the top notch authentic feel throughout the movie. Shooting in real locations amongst real people were a little amateurish at times as a lot of people were peeping into the camera, so were some supporting actors, many whom couldn't handle emotions very well. Music however little it was, sounded excellent, so did the sound mixing.Considering the very delicate subject of poverty and abuse, Capharnaüm kindles our inner feelings to the core in every possible way. It makes us to understand the privileges that we get in our lives has to enjoyed without any complains. Poverty is the worst disease human beings can endure and humanity is the cure for it. A must watch movie for all ages to understand the hardships of life and poverty.

Inhabitants of a capitalist universe, it is natural that, when we go to the movies, we marvel at the wonders that reveal where the capital is. Capernaum subverts this logic by showing or practically spilling on the screen where capital is not.People who stay on the fringes of income distribution are commonly called "economically vulnerable". The film does not stop at political or moral issues, but makes clear that if there is vulnerability in the world, none is greater than that experienced by children.Zain is a boy of about 12 years old (not even the parents know when he was born) getting handcuffed in a court in Beirut. We imagine that it is "naturally" some kind of delinquency that "this kind of people" commits. However, through the narratives, we find that it does not. He has been serving time already for a few years for stabbing a man. What is involved here is a lawsuit, proposed by the boy, against his parents for having committed the "crime" of placing him in the world.The film is a succession of flashbacks that (do not) explain Zain's story but draw a profile of the children's universe in a place where they come to the world trough a religious discourse that masks an odd evil of parents. Ignorant, addicted, and slothful, they do not care a minute worrying about their children's fate. They do not know when they were born, where they are, they do not send them to school, and if an opportunity for profit arises, they do not mind "raffling off" a younger daughter into the ubiquitous lust of human predators.Fleeing from home, Zain receives, perhaps for the first time in his life, a bit of affection and attention from an illegal Ethiopian immigrant Rahil and goes on to take care of her son, the toddler Yonas, who, due to her mother's arrest, becomes a mission of life for the boy.Zain becomes a hero: he becomes gigantic, resilient, he invents unbelievable strategies. However, villains are many, some because they hunt, others because they do not care, others because they deny reality. Victory is impossible, just as this world legion of heroes is disposable.

reviews.review_title: I waited for few weeks to write this
reviews.content: After watching the movie, I was overwhelmed with emotions. This was a powerful cinema. But sometimes this feeling fades as the time passes because of dull moviemaking (ex. Bohemian rhapsody). I wanted to make sure the feeling was true.It was the truest emotional feeling I've experienced provoked by a movie.When Zain smiled, I teared up because the meaning of that smile really resonated with me (because of an exceptional moviemaking).As the time passes, the last shot of Capernaum (and all the other ones) stays with me like I watched it just now, and I think that is the definition of a classic.

This might be the most overwhelmingly powerful film I've ever seen about children. I was briefly overcome by it, which is unusual for me. With this tale of Zain, an existence-battered boy who sues his parents for the cruelty of giving him life, writer-director-actress Nadine Labaki has created a cinema-as-cry-of-anguish.Labaki and DP Christopher Aoun depict contemporary Beirut as a beautiful, swirling hell in which humans, constantly afflicted by scarcity, turn to their most predatory instincts to survive one another's attacks. Seemingly only the most violent and pugnacious instincts can be nurtured in the world depicted in this film. And one senses no impulse towards social reform on the part of the filmmakers. No solution is offered or even suggested. This social order seems to be merely a reflection of the true nature of the human beast. It is surprising and unexplainable, then, that part of this nature is the impulse to care about one another (even if this does not translate into the ability to care for one another) and to, against the character's own stated wishes, remain alive.The non-actor who is the lead performer, Zain Al Rafeea, a Syrian immigrant who has indeed grown up on the streets of Beirut, doesn't so much play the character as inhabit it. One senses that Labaki found someone who, as with Pierre Blaise as the titular character in Malle's "Lacombe, Lucien", actually was the character they were being asked to portray. The complete authenticity of Al Rafeea's behavior rescues the script from a potential problem. The misfortunes of the characters are so numerous and extreme that if the performances had any shade of artificiality the story might have started to seem ridiculous, like an out-of-control Thomas Hardy tale.One finds oneself simultaneously wanting to look away from Zain because the suffering seems so legitimate, and unable to look away. Some morbidly curious part of ourselves wants to try to read in the child's face the horrors that he probably has, in fact, witnessed. When it comes time for Zain to denounce life itself, we sense that the words are coming from the performer as much as the character. This makes them both more piercing, and more cathartic.Watching Capernaum, I found myself comparing it to two American films about harsh childhoods: the surprisingly gritty Hollywood adaptation Precious, and Sean Baker's spectacular indie, The Florida Project. I judge Capernaum to be clearly superior to the former and slightly inferior to the latter. Precious was ultimately, despite its bleak subject matter, a Hollywood film. Every scene was one of despair or hope, as if the two were mutually exclusive, with the resulting dialectic of course ultimately putting hope on top. Labaki does acknowledge moments of playfulness and empathy even in the hellish depths of her film's world. But her characters are totally at the mercy of the material reality around them. In that way, Capernaum is less complex than Baker's film, which subtly switches from the realist-objective to the expressionistic-subjective to show how the human imagination, despite all that besieges it, manages to create moments of beauty from the world around it. Labaki perhaps attempts such a thing in a scene where Zain finds himself in an amusement park, but this scene is the only false-note in the film. It comes off as a tired art-film cliche or a wholly unnecessary "hommage" to canonnical art films of the 1950s and 1960s.I think this is a very fine work of art. I'm glad it was made and am happy I had the chance to see it. I am, however, sympathetic to those who might reject the film. For it dares to ask, "Is the ordeal of human existence worth while?" Given the conclusion it seems to me it undeniably arrives at, some might fairly say, "Better not to have asked the question."

Here, girls are a commodity that can be exchanged for money; A boy is a tool for bringing home the bacon and caring for younger children. reviews.review_title: Strong emotional movie with a message
reviews.content: Capernaum is a great foreign language film, with an interesting story that is based on real problems. It will touch you because the characters are heartwarming and perfectly written. I did not expect such a great outcome and was happy to be surprised after watching it. Its 2 hours run time does not feel long but thoughtful paced. The movie gives you moments that are so cute and heartwarming only to give you a few scenes later the brutal reality of poverty. This is how you draw attention on a critical topic, wirh a great movie and not just political messages.I can only recommend this picture to you.

The logline of the movie itself reveals the idea of Capernaum, in which it states about a pre-teen boy named Zian sues his parents for the 'crime' that they have done, ie, giving birth to him. It is the catchy element in the movie and the rest of the visuals draw us into the clear picture of what Zain talked about. Zian is surrounded by a lot of siblings and his father and mother are planning for another baby. His life condition (which means his family's life condition) is worse in the sense they don't even care about their children. Zain doing a job in a provision store near his dilapidated house and he earns for his family. Ho doesn't even get an education not even his siblings too. That pathetic condition is clear in each and every corner of the movie. When his sister (she achieved puberty now) put up in the swirl of marriage Zian fought against his father and mother and then he eloped from his family. From there on, the cinema attains an emotional dimension deeply. When Zain babysits Rihal's (an Ethiopean lady who is doing multi-tasking jobs) toddler, Yohan he feels some kind of security and protection from there. Even though Rihal is living more pathetically than Zian lived, Zian adjusts to the situation and he gets love to care for the first time in his life. He looks after Yohan as his brother. On an occasion when he questions himself about the color of Yohan and him (because Zian is white), he states that while Yohan was pregnant his mother drank a lot more coffee. Likewise, that kind of innocence can be seen in the attitude of Zian, but actually, he doesn't know how to show it. You can see Zian smiling only at the end of the movie. In that way, Capernaum flows exactly as chaos and that's why Zian filed a case against his parents to bring him into this chaotic world. Capernaum shed our tears, it'll stay back in our minds and disturb us, and also it will glow upon our souls and resounds how lucky we are.

reviews.review_title: Movies that matter, really powerful and moving picture.
reviews.content: Zain is a young Lebanese boy who is completely neglected and abused by his parents. He's never attended school and is forced to work at a grocery store for groceries and other necessities.He has many siblings but he is really close to his younger sister. Things go from bad t9 worse when his sister is sold into mariage by his parents, so Zain runs away from home. Zain ends up living with a Ethiopian migrant (Rahil) and her toddler son.Things turn sour once again as Rahil is arrested for working without a permit and Zain is left to take care of Rahil's lil boy.I do not want to spoil the whole movie but take my word for it this movie will make you angry, make you cry and make you laugh out loud.
Stop having kids if you can't take care of them - Subtle message explained beautifully.

I was a major fan of last year's THE INSULT and was curious to see this at TIFF. Let's just say it has nowhere near the maturity, insight, and prowess of Ziad Doueiri's work. At the screening for CAPARNAUM, we saw several people rolling their eyes at what is so clearly a film designed to make a person cry -- and so cheaply. The fact that the director cast herself as a legal "savior" to the little boy says it all.

A compelling and stunning movie that is by no means perfect, and there are points where it's in danger of becoming an overly documented look at the horrors of living in the third world instead of fleshing out into a fully explained narrative, but that's not really the point because the focus is on telling how it really is in the most unobtrusive way possible, as though it's being documented for real in a story about extreme hardship and poverty.It reminded me of my first experience with Schindler's List, and that's the reason I'm only giving it an 8, because it doesn't have the grandeur and underlying story to propel it into classic status, but some of the camera work and top-down looks at the deep-rooted depravity of destitute people, which is cleverly portrayed by some wonderful and ingenious cinematography in contrast to how disgusting everything appears in such a destroyed and poor world, is startling.A very thought-provoking film that makes you realize just how lucky most of us are to have 'normal' lives and not be subjected to any of this. Thank God!

reviews.review_title: An accurate glimpse into the plight of the refugee
reviews.content: What a truly touching film. I cried incessantly. The story of Zain and his struggle as an abused child living in abject poverty is a must-see for the many spoiled, ungrateful brats residing in North America. And by North America, I mean the continent, not the northern U.S! While people in the U.S., Canada, and other countries complain about trivial things such as not having a brand-new car, children like Zain and his siblings suffer immensely. They do not even have blankets, or their own separate beds. I do not want to give too much away, but I must say that this is a beautiful, profound film. The protagonist forms a close bond with a young woman who is an illegal resident. He is a very sweet, protective little boy with a heart of gold, despite having horrible, negligent parents. Whatever your opinion about refugees and illegal immigration, this movie will tug at the heartstrings.

The title of the film is "how to be a home", ostensibly, it is a story about a 12-year-old homeless boy who yearns for a home and the love of his parents, but when he cannot get it, he hates home and runs away from home. But the social problems it reflects are deplorable. The shadow of war can be seen everywhere. After watching the film, we all have a common wish, that is, the film at the end of the title: wish every child be treated gently. "Home" was originally a warm harbour, in the film we saw was "native families" and "environment" the tragedy of the extension, environmental impact, this sentence is right, the real story is always someone attention, as our protagonist zane al lafite the same, only hope this miserable childhood, become memories, after all only hope that the future of him, "all good".

Most of the time I review movies by writing paragraphs about cinematography, acting performance, plot. But I think I can describe this movie by just one word: Brutal. Don't think of it as a blood hell movie people just killing each other for no realistic reasons. But brutally realistic.The movie takes place in Lebanon. You may have heard something about how worthless human lives are in Arab countries. But hearing is simply not enough. This movie takes you to there and makes you live in the streets. Misery is everywhere. People are starving and everybody needs to think of theyselves because otherwise they will starve too. But they still continue to breed with incredible speed. This situation has its own reasons (which are compelitely unacceptable). But you know, you can't really understand it until you live it. The kid sues his parents for making him. He literally prefers not exist to this life. After all, is what happened to him his fault? Aren't his parents supposed to give him at least a better life? When you have a child, don't you agree to offer him a healthy life?The scenes are good but not great. You feel the crowded Lebanon streets with the great camera angles. The "realistic shaking camera" tactic is very useful in movies like these. Because you need to feel anxiety, the camera needs to move like your eyes, not knowing where to focus. The music wasn't really still in my ears, so I count this as a fail. Most of the time I always search the movies OST in internet after I finish the movies. But this movie didn't hit me with its music.I always say there is an unnecessary hype with kids acting. If they act avarage people hype them like they acted like a Dicaprio or something like that. I am sorry but acting is a serious job. It affects very heavily how the movie tastes. So we can't classify actors/actresses are kids/adults. I don't really remember a specific acting other then Yordanos Shiferaw. Her mother reactions was realistic. I really surprised when I saw she has no other works. Maybe she is a theater actress, I don't know. Hope best for her future.This movie comes with good -but not great- plot. Leaves you with questions about an important philosophy. Antinatalism. Great cinematography (visual) and good acting. Don't expect a mind blowing movie and you'll have a good time.

The acting in this film is phenomenal. It takes us out of our comfort zone and is a stark reminder as to how lucky many of us are. What really made this movie so exceptional was the raw talent of Zain. His suffering was so real! Interesting that many of the actors real lives resembles the characters they portrayed in the movie. Zain was actually a Syrian refugee living in Lebanon when this was filmed, perhaps explains why the acting is so good.

reviews.review_title: Survival / Love/ Love Lost / Innocence Lost
reviews.content:
It's hard to imagine this existence. Especially for Americans that have no true idea.
Zain Al Rafeea portrays a young Lebanese boy who with his dirt poor but large family work hard and learn hard just to survive. A street smart Zain has the heart of a lion and knows how to operate inside & outside the law for his and his loved ones survival. When his 11 yr old sister that he is protective of is removed the the picture Zains rage grows & is too hard to bare & he leaves home in a place where humanity hangs by a thread everyday. Whilst searching for her, he finds other people , other situations . It is amazing that a modern day Syria/ Lebanon and other like minded area countries exist with such immoral ideas in their everyday lives. The future of these 3rd world genocidic countries rest squarely on the shoulders of such hopeful future leaders made from the same clay that Zain is made.
Live Simply so that Others can Simply Live. A decent. To survive on those streets is truly an absolutely stunning feat for a 12 yr old "man" A satisfying watch with an ending that could have been better and at least lied to the viewers for more of a satisfying closure.

I saw this film at TIFF with high expectations but was shocked but was shocked by how removed the filmmaker was from this issue. Scene after scene of melodrama, clearly crafted by a person of privilege as opposed to someone who really understands this subject enough personally to make it more human as opposed to caricature and demeaning. On a technical level, the shaky camera and repetitive drone shots played into the worst visual cliches of modern filmmaking (as if one must show shaky camera footage when depicting poverty).

This is a great movie for grownups about kids. I cannot imagine how the director managed to get the performance out of the toddler. We see so many films about American dysfunctional families. The dysfunction of this family hits an unbelievable new low!

reviews.review_title: Great topic with annoying camera shaking

I write this as an NGO worker who was fortunate enough to travel to Cannes, as my husband is a journalist. There was no film I was more eager to see, as the subject is related to my exact profession, and I am a female film-lover always cheering on women directors. Let's just say I was left with far more love for the female-directed HAPPY AS LAZZARO. I work with street children in Lebanon. As a film-lover, I found the film a bit derivative of other films by Danny Boyle, especially in its speed and camera work. But as a human being close to this cause, the film angered me beyond belief. It is pornographic and exploitative as everyone is saying. The children are "cutified" if that could be a word, primed for a foreign audience. The Ethiopian was portrayed as a "Magical Negro," clearly implanted into the story as a parachute. The parents are one-dimensional and monstrous, which is not the case typically at all. There is no credibility to the story. I hope for a powerful documentary that can serve as a rebuttal to what I can only and sadly describe as manipulative Oscar bait, very carefully -- and so savvily -- constructed for foreign audiences with good intentions who might not see how awful the film truly is.

The movie is beautifully shot and very well acted, the minimal cast stand out against the grimy setting and the injustice of their terrible circumstances.
Zain and Yosef play their parts perfectly.
If you think you have daily problems, and many of us do, take a look at what these children have to face.

reviews.review_title: Capharnaüm : A interesting and touching take on the humanitarian crises.
reviews.content:
When I went into this movie I didn't know what to expect. I imagined a full on trial kind of movie but this movie focuses on how the different allegations are justified and how the situation derivated to the disaster it became.
A very hard to watch movie because of its realistic approach to the life of those who suffered under war,humanitarian and the crises of globalisation.

reviews.review_title: An uplifting hope in a broken homeless kid showed to those who lost the meaning of life.
reviews.content:
As a Lebanese filmmaker, I admit that Capharnaüm is one of the best film from Lebanon, and if you like this film I recommend "The insult" "Ghadi" "And where do we go now" and my first film "Broken Truth" and many other good Lebanese films. Life can be tough. Zain, a 12-year-old boy from Beirut, can tell you a thing or two about it. Poverty, neglect of education, domestic violence, child labor instead of school and the lack of any official ID are some key words to describe his situation. After having run away from his family, he ends up as a baby sitter of the illegal boy of an Ethiopian cleaning lady. When the latter is arrested, Zain is left behind with the full responsibility for the survival of the infant.The movie shows all this with a straight ruthlessness but the story also has its caring and fun moments, so that it does not ever become unbearable. Moreover, the dense pictures of Beirut street life are really compelling. That none of the passersby reacts, when bedraggled Zain, in his efforts to organize some food, pushes the baby through the streets in a pot placed on a stolen skateboard, may seem strange but only shows that poverty is no longer seen when it is surrounded by poverty.The story covers some other hot topics like human trafficking, Syrian refugees in Lebanon or child marriage. This all comes across very realistic and the inside Lebanese view makes it even more convincing.Then the movie also raises the moral question whether parents should have even more children, when it is already clear that they cannot care for the existing ones. A hard one but at least Zain has found a clear answer to it, which makes him sue his parents for having him born.A bit irritating for my taste was the fact that Zain is way too small and wispy for a 12 year old. Why not let him be 10 and the story would still be the same. On the other hand, the 12 years are only a guess by a doctor when examining Zain's teeth, since Zain himself does not really know his own age ...Despite all, the movie ends with a happy end. Not a fairy tale one, but Zain eventually turns into an official human being simply by being registered in prison. There is thus hope for a change for the better.

Why did you sue your parents?
Because they brought me to the world.
Please, those who cannot raise children should not have children.

Would you like to connect yourself with human nature? Well, this movie is for you. Meaningful productions as Capernaum deserves all the attention and support. Two hours that shows an unbelievable reality through an impeccable direction and prominent natural performances. Even though Capernaum means chaos -which is undeniable- you should experience a powerful sensation of aesthetics and hope.

In the film Capernaum there was a lot of things that I had learned in international relations such as child marrying, International Development, human trafficking, forced labor, child labor, and refugees. In Lebanon you walk down the streets and see children working, selling gum, and dragging gas canisters miles down the road. The streets are always busy and the parents are nowhere to be found. The children are all exhausted and restless with dirt all around them. They don't get treated nicely and get beat up by any adult. Throughout the film you see a wide variety of different religious beliefs and different hierarchy classes. The story began with Zain and his parents in court. Zain had been a juvenile for stabbing someone and wanted to sue his parents for child neglect and for being born.The story scene then shifts into the past where the story really began, which was at Zain's place to eat, sleep, and take care of his siblings. One of the siblings was chained to a wall crying. It was a very tight space with only a couple rooms. The father and mother smoked a lot of cigarettes in front of their children and would just smoke and sleep all day. The parents feed their children sugar and ice as a meal and have their children work to make money for the family. The parents are dependent on Zain to bring back their needs and to not screw up at work or else they will be living without a roof over them. The mother had numerous children and all were very young. The mother did not care for any of the children especially when she sold her own eleven year old daughter to a grown man to get married. In exchange they were given a couple of chickens. None of the children go to school to get an education as well.Sahar and Zain had a very strong relationship and Zain cared for Sahar very much. When Sahar got her period for the first time Zain gave her his shirt and told her not to tell the parents. The reasoning was because Sahars friend was kicked out of the house after getting her period and Zain did not want anything to happen to Sahar. Sahar had a relationship with an older guy, Assad, who Zain had worked for. Zain tried to make an escape plan with Sahar by saving up a ton of money from his job and getting a lot of food for them but she was already taken to Assad. This part of the film shows child marrying which is very sad because she was not ready to get married. Towards the end of the film Sahar actually passes away from being pregnant meaning she was raped by her so called "husband."Zain is a part of a Syrian refugee family who was very poor. The parents didn't work which caused the family to be in poverty and have starving children. The parents throughout the film did not really care for their children; they would use their children to sell and get more food and or money. In the small space with a numerous number of children in the household. Many of the children were mostly little girls and none of them were in their teenage years yet. They all slept on the same mattress without any blankets or covers. There was one cover that was used to separate the parents from the children. None of the children had papers because they were all refugees. Zain would get slapped and thrown around by his parents and all Zain could do was to just let it all happen.The oldest was a little boy named Zain who was believed to be 12. Zain was asked by the judge what his age was and he told the judge to ask his parents. The reasoning behind this was because Zain did not have any birth certificate or paper work that showed when he was born and how old he actually was. Zain is the main character throughout this film. He worked to keep his family happy and brought food back to his family as well. He also took care of his siblings and watched after them everyday. At work he would lug around gas canisters and deliver food to people miles away. He worked from broad daylight all the way to night. His siblings and he would set up stands on the busy Lebanon streets and sell tomato juice and beetroot juice. Another clip showed the children selling chewing gum. Sahar was getting sexually assaulted by men on the street and Zain had to protect her from the men.One thing that Zain would do illegally was steal food from the corner shop that he worked at. Since his family could not put food out on a plate for all their children. Zain also would go to drug stores and give them fake prescriptions to get different medications. He was told to do this by his parents, showing that they do not care for their children and rather use them to not get in trouble. With the drugs the family comes together to smash the drugs into tiny pieces and use them to wash clothes that are then given to a cousin in jail.Once Zain had run away he met an old man on the bus who called himself Cockroach- man. Zain saw him get off the bus at a carnival and decided to go check it out. He slept at the carnival and ate what he had left. At one point he was on top of a ride and a lady who was cleaning the windows saw him. Zain went where the lady was and she gave him food to eat. Tigest, an Ethiopian immigrant who had a son named Yonas, was eagerly working to keep her and her son alive and avoid getting deported. She knew that when she was caught and deported her son would be taken from her and she would be alone in her country. At work she would keep her son in a bathroom locked up and once she was done working she would put her son in a bag so that no one knew she had a son. Tigest got her fake ID from a man named Aspro. Aspro told Tigest if she didn't have the money she would need to give her son Yonas to him. When Zain was left alone with Yonas he tried his best to take care of him but in the end went to Aspro for help. Tigest was arrested for being an immigrant. In the jail the cells were split up into different religious beliefs and different tribes were locked up together as well. Which also led him to a little girl selling flowers on the street showing child labor. Aspro told Zain he could get him to a different country and had different trips around the world. All Zain needed was a photo showing he was human. Zain then gave Aspro Yonas.In the end Zain is shown going back to his home and asking his parents for his papers not knowing they are refugees. So he did not have any papers. His father then shows a hospital bill and Zain asks who was in the hospital. It was his sister Sahar who passed away from her pregnancy. Zain then grabs a knife and runs down the street of Lebanon to stab Assad. He is then put in juvenile prison and sees Tigest. His mother came to visit him one day to tell him she was pregnant with another baby. She told him she wishes it was a girl because then she could name it Sahar. Zain was furious and told his mom he never wants to see her again. Zain's court case was shown live on television and Zain had a few words to say to parents who couldn't afford to take care of their children. Aspro was shown being arrested for keeping people captive and having them do forced laboring for him. The military found Yonas in a box by himself. In the end Yonas is given back to Tigest before getting deported and Zain gets his picture taken for his ID.

I'm not someone who gets emotional watching drama. But this movie is a beast entirely in its own league. Zain's performance is so well done, you really connect with his sadness, his struggle, and even his short moments of small joy. I wept uncontrollably for the entire second half. The movie feels like a documentary, and it very well could be. Countless people live with such intense suffering, pain and grief, it's hard not to feel sorry for the sad world we live in.Capernaum is an excellent movie. It's brutal in presentation. It will make your heart wrench. This story needs to be told, and heard, and recognized, because this is the life of so many people.

Capernaum is a movie about a young boy, named Zain, who lives in a poor city in Lebanon. Throughout the film we see how Zain is emotionally impacted by the poverty and poor conditions he grew up in. Zain, a twelve-year-old boy who is incredibly mature for his age, becomes fed up with the selfish actions of his parents, and ends up making very significant decisions. Three common themes or topics seen throughout Zain's journey include gender, human trafficking, and migration and refugees.The first theme, gender, seems to play a large role in the lives of people and families during the movie. As seen in many places throughout the world, Zain's home city of Beirut views men as the providers for the family, while women stay home and take care of the house and the children. In their culture, it is typically custom for women/girls to marry a man and start a family at a young age. Often times the girls do not have a say in who they marry, as the fathers of the husband and wife make arrangements for the marriage. When Zain noticed a blood stain in his sister Sahar's sheets, he immediately became worried for her because he feared that his parents would sell her into marriage in exchange for goods. His family was poor, and he feared that his parents would be fine with giving her away even at the age of eleven. He took matters into his own hands and got her pads and helped her hide her period. This also relates to the theme of gender because it shows that the older brother was providing for his sister even at such a young age, which ties into gender roles. Another common topic throughout the film that relates to gender is education. It seems as if only boys go to school in their society. In the beginning of the movie, Zain's parents considered sending him to school in order for him to learn, be fed, and receive new clothes. Zain was twelve, while Sahar was eleven. This means that they were around the same age, however, their parents only ever talked about sending Zain to school. It seems as if in their culture, girls and women are not able to receive education, as they are expected to marry a man who can provide for them.Another topic that was seen in the film was human trafficking. This topic first occurred when Zain's sister, Sahar, got her first period. As soon as Zain saw the blood stain in her sheets, he recognized the possibility that she could be sent into marriage against her will. Human trafficking often consists of people selling or giving away children in exchange for goods or services. Unfortunately, many cases of human trafficking are sexually motivated. In this case, Zain and Sahar's parents sold Sahar into marriage in exchange for two chickens, due to the fact that they were poor. In simple terms, they received goods and in exchange they gave away their eleven year old child, knowing that she would be forced into sex in order to have a child. This frustrated Zain, as he ran away from his family when they gave her away. Later in the film, Zain found out that Sahar died during her pregnancy. An eleven year old, forced into a marriage, is clearly not developed enough to go through the steps of pregnancy. This shows how twisted their culture is. Although this is a fictional film, viewers of the movie learn about similar topics that occur in real life. Young girls are often sold into a marriage, even though they are clearly not ready to have a child. Zain recognized the unfairness of this exchange, causing him to leave. When he left, he came across Rahil, the mother of a very young child name Yonas. Throughout Zain's experiences with Rahil and Yonas, human trafficking in introduced yet again. When Rahil gets arrested, Zain has to take care of baby Yonas. He comes across Aspro, a man who is able to provide people with opportunities such as leaving the country. Aspro is determined to buy Yonas, and offers Zain money to own and "take care of Yonas. Zain, desperately, ends up giving Yonas to Aspro and although the film didn't show how Yonas was treated, it is safe to say that Aspro should not have been able to "buy" Yonas. This relates to human trafficking because it shows how a child was sold to a man in exchange for money. Zain eventually returned Yonas to his mother, but in my opinion, no person, especially a baby, should be sold to a another person in exchange for money without the mother's approval. This movie really highlighted the issues that occur in areas of poverty such as Beirut. The topic of human trafficking is a recurring theme throughout the film that shows how much should be changed in these areas.A third and final topic that was prevalent throughout the film is migration and refugees. Many people in the middle east are determined to leave their country in hopes of a better life. The first example of migration is Rahil. She moved to Lebanon and was determined to live there and raise her son. However, she did not live there legally, which is why she got arrested. Another example of migration is Zain. Zain met a girl who said she had hopes of moving to Sweden. This seems to influence Zain a lot. He was determined to get out of Lebanon. He started selling drugs to addicts in hopes of making some money to help him leave the country. The fact that a child at such a young age was determined to leave his country by himself shows how bad the conditions are in this area. Many people leave their countries as a result of poverty, violence, war, or other issues. This film really highlights that fact. It vividly illustrates the struggles people face in the middle east.Overall, I really enjoyed watching this film. I think it was very interesting, but more importantly it educates viewers on the problems that occur in less developed countries. The topics of gender, human trafficking, and migration/refugees are all very prevalent throughout the film. Zain is faced with all three of these and even though he was so young, he managed to take care of himself and others while dealing with the obstacles thrown his way.

I happened to see these three movies within 4 days of one another, and this movie had the strongest impact on me.First, I had no idea what to expect. I read about a 12 years boy suing his parents. It didn't sound particularly interesting, but I was blown away when I saw this movie today. Beautifully directed, raw with emotions, and with great acting, particularly by Zain, the 12 year old boy. The toddler was amazing too. Nadine Labaki has done a great job directing this movie.I had never seen a movie from Lebanon, and knew very little about that country, outside of politics. There is poverty in all countries. It is just that movies don't always show it. They actually try to run away from those issues. Nadine Labaki's Capernaum is a brutally honest look at the impoverished existence of 12-year old Beirut slum-dweller, Zain (played by the precocious Zain Al Rafeea) as he takes matters into his own hands and sues his neglectful parents for "being born". Capernaum has been the recipient of many awards worldwide including, significantly, the Jury Prize at Cannes in 2018. The film's synopsis led me to thinking about the modern concept of childhood in general. Though the conditions which Zain is fighting in Capernaum are exceptional, it is interesting to note how children across the world, at an increasingly early age, are acting more like adults, to the point where an innocent childhood is perhaps bypassed completely. This fact is, questionably, the fault of technology.On planes and trains, there is the increasing sight of tablets and other technical paraphernalia being thrust into the hands of children to keep them quiet, some of whom are so young they can barely hold the things. And, there is s a danger, is there not, in letting children have unfiltered access to a wealth of information online which their brains are surely too young to compute? I was recently in earshot of some preadolescents who were talking with their parents about the recent Extinction Rebellion protests. This precocious intelligence was indeed scary.Having said all this, returning to the cinema, it's not the first time the movies have embraced the idea of children becoming premature adults through circumstance. More than half a century ago, Italian director Vittorio De Sica came to the fore with his Neorealist masterpiece, Bicycle Thieves (1948), in which a little working-class boy called Bruno (Enzo Staiola) helps his father Antonio (Lamberto Maggiorani) to find his bicycle after it's stolen. This, in turn, gave inspiration to French New Wave director, François Truffaut, who a decade later produced his chef d'oeuvre, The 400 Blows (1959), about a young Parisian adolescent, Antoine Doinel (Jean-Pierre Léaud) who is forced into premature adulthood at the hands of neglectful parents who leave him to fend for himself to the point of making him run away from home completely.Returning to modern filmmaking, this theme runs again in Sean Baker's wonderful pseudo-documentary, The Florida Project (2017), about the precocious 6 year old, Moonee (Brooklynn Prince) who lives with her troubled mother Halley (Bria Vinaite) in a cramped motel room in the shadow of the lucrative mecca that is Disneyworld. While all these films are sad, they are successful precisely because of the precocity of their child stars.

reviews.review_title: tailor-made for hunting a festival prize?
reviews.content:
This is definitely one of the most intriguing, provocative, heart blowing and irritating movies I've ever watched, this is the type of movies that leaves you in a disturbed state of mind while gazing at the credits scrolling down on the screen, it's hard to formulate a solid impression on such movies, it's definitely impressive and humane, but not necessarily in a positive way.
First of all let me confess that I couldn't determine the logic behind the movie name, when I googled "Capernaum" I found out it's the name of a small Palestinian town overlooking the Sea of Galilee, the movie could be referring to it as the location where events are set, or it could be meant as just a symbol of any Arab city, however the movie held many clear indicators that it was set in Beirut and that the main character "Zain" was Lebanese.
I believe that the message meant by the movie is really significant and
substantial, people shall cease from bringing new children to the world unless they are capable of raising them up properly and of securing their basic needs of shelter, food, healthcare and education, I'm not quite sure whether Lebanon is suffering from a serious over-population issue or it was just a general message the makers of the movie wanted to deliver.
Nadine Labaki is a very talented and artistically-motivated director, here 2 previous movies (Caramel 2007 and Where Do We Go Now? 2011) have been wonderfully charming, this one, however, is much less entertaining, and that's - in my opinion - is its main issue, cinema after all is an entertainment art, I appreciate the joy I feel when watching a well-made movie, and there is a thin line between entertainment and message, every movie maker has to respect that line and keep his movie balanced between both, in this movie I've been constantly molested by ugly views of slums (not that the camera views were ugly but the places themselves were) and aggressive scenes, that started from the very first frame to the very last one throughout 2 hours, at least some nice landscapes or enchanting scenes would have helped interrupt this harsh atmosphere.
One other concern I have is the feeling that some movies nowadays, especially in the third world countries - and even in Hollywood and Europe but within different aspects - are being tailor-made for film festivals and academy awards, some approaches and subjects are being celebrated and carefully framed to qualify for hunting a festival prize, for example poverty, breach of human rights, forced marriage of minors, people trafficking, child labor, enslavement of refugees and foreign labor, etc., this movie is a perfect paradigm of such movies, I believe that Nadine's two previous movies were much more intimate, affectionate, well-focused and - above all - more cinematographically enchanting.

Parenting is not something we are naturally gifted at, regardless of what we're usually told that it's our biological destiny. In other words, raising a child and giving them a chance to become a good person is a tough task requiring a lot of work and sacrifices from parents. Unfortunately, some people take it for granted that everybody should bring children to this world. Moreover, their offspring must even be grateful for whatever life they've been given, however pathetic it might be.The movie tells us a story about such an egoistic couple who've recklessly conceived several children without any actual wish to be responsible for them, let alone take care of them. We see how the children are left to suffering in the slums of Beirut, and it's incredibly tough to watch. Even though it's revealed from the very beginning where the main character ends up, it doesn't make the whole tragedy less painful.On the other hand, isn't it exactly what movies are supposed to prompt in us? The real emotions, the tangible feelings that make us uncomfortable when we watch it all on screens at our cozy homes, maybe even having a delicious meal in front of us. It's important to clash such realities to cook a delicious meal to our minds as well and thus to have a look at ourselves from another perspective. On top of that, it's definitely recommended for parents to watch, especially for prospective ones, so that they could one more time reconsider that imperative decision they're about to take.After all, it can be easy to justify inevitability of the depicted tragedy by societal pressure in such a conservative and religious place as Lebanon. To cap it all, it's not a well-off country either. However, the problem appears universal and is unrelated to family income: even in affluent societies money can't replace parents' love, the unity of a family along with lots of truths and discoveries it exposes, which is all certain to play an important part in a growing human's life.

Review: Capernaum (2018)
Capernaum, 'chaos', follows the dismal struggle of Zain El-Hajj, a 12-year-old Lebanese boy suing his parents for the 'crime' of giving him, and his numerous siblings, life. At its premier at Cannes Film Festival in 2018, the screenplay, directed by Nadine Labaki, received a 15-minute standing ovation for its highly relevant and moving depiction of the increasingly dire situation for the majority living in Lebanon. Since October, nationwide protests have railed against government corruption and economic mismanagement, making Capernaum more relevant than ever, as it succeeds in depicting the resulting injustice of the poverty beckoned by years of growing crisis. According to a 2015 United Nations study, 77 percent of Lebanese residents were deprived in terms of economic status, but what film helps to achieve is the creation of pathos for the emotional and psychological effects of these stats, which increasingly fail to shock and evoke anger in our country, which seems to look more and more inwardly in its concerns and worries, with a certain 'every man for himself' attitude permeating politics and ethics in our post-Brexit era.
Zain, played by Syrian born actor Zain al-Rafeea, escapes his home in the slums of Beirut after his beloved sister is given away for marriage by their parents to a man twice her senior. While wondering the streets, he comes across Rahil, an immigrant hiding her undocumented son while working under a false identity. Zain becomes Yonas' primary carer and friend when Rahel is arrested, unbeknownst to him, and his suffering and desperation for survival is captured in his growing anger and frustration of his helpless situation as the film continues. Zain's character is not entirely separate from the actor's reality, as he grew up in the slums of Beirut himself after escaping the conflict in Syria, and was illiterate at the time of filming, so the integrity of his role is evident in his convincing and natural performance. Now living in Norway, he is a success story of children like Zain, his character in the film, who attempt to flee their conditions of poverty. The plot touches on Zain's desire and attempt to leave Lebanon by boat, an outcome which could have been disastrous had it succeeded, seeing as 3,740 deaths occurred among refugees at sea in 2016 alone. Instead, Zain ends up in prison for what he describes in court at the beginning of the film as 'stabbing a mother****er', whose identity is not revealed until later in the plot, leaving the audience unsure of what fate would have been worse.
Capernaum is ultimately a film of moral dilemmas, which we as a Western audience are forced to contemplate from a position of privilege, but which we are made sympathetic towards through the struggles of each character. What sits most uncomfortably is the role of the parents in the 'chaos', seeing as they enabled Zain and his siblings' misery through their neglect and irresponsible continuation of having more children than they could cope with. However, viewers will also come to see the injustice of one-sided blaming, as it is the system of government and a lack of help for citizens which also denies the basic desire to love and be loved, something achieved through parenthood. This dilemma stays with viewers for days, and I would recommend Capernaum to anyone feeling downhearted in their current situation, as it certainly puts into perspective our own problems with those of others across the globe.

reviews.review_title: A story of chaos, forgiveness and peace.
reviews.content:
The film has so many layers of complexity within it because of the many events that lead to its making.
During the mid 70s and into the early 90s, Lebanon was in war with Syria among other neighboring countries. The Syrian army invaded the country and controlled most of Northern Lebanon. Much destruction was caused in Beirut as a result of the constant war. What most people don't know is that Lebanon got bombed over and over by the Syrian army for almost two decades until its liberation from Syria in 2005.
Now keeping all of that in mind, the female director and mother of two children, Nadine Labaki (who endured this war), made this film with all this in mind.
Lebanon is actually smaller than Los Angeles county. It now harbors more Syrian refugees than the country can contain. Today, there are almost the same amount of Lebanese people as there are Syrian refugees. I was in Lebanon 3 years ago and it was shocking to see refugees living in the abandoned destroyed buildings that their army destroyed in Lebanon; Some are literally living in the skeletons of past destruction. Yet, with all that, the director Nadine Labaki chose a Syrian refugee, Zain, to star in her film. She could have easily chosen a Lebanese boy to play the role of a Lebanese child, but she chose him in particular for a reason.
In the end, this film, in my humble opinion, is really a story of peace and forgiveness and a call for the world to care for its children. After all, the children of today, are our future who will direct a new path in our world.
The Lebanese community is embracing the children of its once rival neighboring country that destroyed a good part of Lebanon less than two decades ago.
If Lebanon is able to forgive and forget to help the children, then any country should be able to the same.
The ending of the film was truly captivating. The peaceful smile of a child that just wants to belong, co-exist and live in peace.

Very real and sad and tragic.

When journalists question Labaki about her "film", she mentions the great political cause that drove her to make it. She speaks of the misery she witnessed, the poor street children whom she drove by one day, her lucky young actor who was granted a visa to Norway thanks to her impactful film, etc. But she carefully avoids talking about... her film. She'd much rather talk about everything around it, leaving aside any potential ideas regarding her actual cinema. Why? Because she doesn't have a distinct cinematic voice, so she really doesn't have anything interesting to say about her own film. And because, as Godard said, "cinema is a form that thinks and a thought that forms", this complete lack of voice is obvious in her film, which is full of gimmicks, superfluous scenes, and an outrageous "cathartic happy end" worthy of a propaganda film: a (deplorable) government, a lawyer (shamelessly played by Labaki herself) and the media (known for their unprofessionalism) all contribute to rescue the hero, punish the bad guys and restore order and justice. (I say the Lebanese government is "deplorable" because it still practices torture, gender discrimination, racial discrimination, among a variety of other human rights violations). Formally, the film is shot with a Steadicam and the few drone shots are just there to highlight urban poverty. The fast-paced editing doesn't leave the audience time to actually look at faces and find genuine expressions in them. Our eyes are never free to wander around the frame - viewers don't even have time to think, because they're being held hostage by this chaotic and tearjerking mise-en-scene which desperately begs for their empathy but quickly becomes irritating.Labaki invented a new genre: the cinema-mensonge. Canne's Thierry Frémaux made her famous, probably for strategic reasons. But that's his problem. Film critics and cinephiles are not blind, and they saw the film for what it is: a calculated exploitation of misery made by an uninspired and narcissistic filmmaker.
The drama in this movie will not give you a break. It is an endless ride of sorrow and and hopelessness. It is a must watch.

A serious hats off to director Nadine Labaki for what is accurately being labeled a "masterpiece."At points I felt that the story-line exceeded what is possible in reality, but that did not take away from the unbelievable creativity employed to weave together so many political and social-economic issues. Walking out of the theater, I noted to a friend that it makes one recall that there is an entire underworld that most people are unaware of, one of poverty, hunger and deep repression. He replied noting that the majority of the world lives there, it's just us unaware. That sums up so much of what this movie is all about and why we all have the uncomfortable duty to educate ourselves beyond social media slogans and quips and address it head on.Capernaüm has already won 27 awards and has been nominated for 36. It has been nominated for an Oscar, which is a no-brainer once you have watched it.

Capernaum is a difficult film that deals with the complex socio-economic problems of an underdeveloped and poor country such as Lebanon and how such a situation in the country and society affects an average family. It is brutal in its realism and will not leave anyone indifferent. The plot of the film revolves around a main character named Zain who is 12 or 13 years old (neither he knows exactly nor his parents because they have no papers and he is not reported to have been born), young but highly intelligent for his age, who fights against, poverty and destitution given to him at birth. Zain is the oldest child in his family, and the exact number of brothers and sisters is not shown to us in the film, which is what the director wants to show contradictory that in such a society, children are considered numbers. Young Zain cares most about his sister Sahra, who is about 12 years old and who is just entering puberty, but in a society where it is allowed to marry a girl who has just started getting a sexual graduation, he understands what that means. She decides to run away together with Sahra, who is not even aware of what is to come, but her parents have already arranged the marriage, and they have chosen a young man in their twenties who can help them financially. Due to the impossibility of a way to oppose his parents and that marriage, Zain decides to run away from home and then he will find out that the world he knew is even worse. He introduces a migrant woman to a baby from Ethiopia who fled illegally because of the war, whose life gets worse when she is arrested without paperwork, and young Zain decides to sell her to a man who trades people who promise him life in the western country. The baby is guaranteed by a foster family. Zain later finds out that his sister Zahra passed away due to complications related to the pregnancy, and then decides to take revenge. He stabs her sister's husband with a knife after which he is arrested and at the trial, in addition to the trial against him, he leads a counter-trial in which he sues his parents because he was born. At the end of the film, the baby is returned to its mother, the smuggler is arrested and Zain is photographed for the papers when we first time see his smile in the film.No one should lead this kind of life, without any social protection, but people, and unfortunately also children, live this kind of life. The director and director of the casting have just been looking for actors whose lives closely follow the background stories of the characters they play. Zain worked as a delivery man when he was only 10, and his sister in the film is a Syrian refugee who was discovered when she was selling chewing gum on the streets of Beirut. Zain's parents are so poor that they can't afford to pay the bill for his birth, which means that Zain can't get personal documents and therefore can't have a passport, receive medical care or go to school, so he is forced to work as a he would feed himself and his family. In the Middle East, marriage is directly linked to reaching sexual maturity (unlike European culture, where time and partner selection have a high degree of independent decision-making), but it also depends to a large extent on family interests and considerations. What also distinguishes this culture from the European one is the number of children in the family. In Europe, there is a tendency to reduce the number of children in order to achieve a "demographic transition", and to reduce mortality, especially child mortality, and then in the next step there is a reduction in birth rates. In Zain's family, children are numbers, they are considered a blessing, but their future is not considered. After Sahra's death, Zain's mother tells him "when God takes something from you, he blesses you in return", telling him that she is pregnant again, completely unaware of the world she is bringing her newborn into. She tells him that she hopes to be a daughter (she hopes because she knows that she has more benefits from a female child because she can marry her in 13,14 years and use her for financial gain as was the case with Sahra) to which Zain tells her that she does not have a heart and not wanting to see her, obviously aware of the situation.

Misery porn doesn't automatically make for good drama, and Capernaum is proof positive of that sentiment; the film often features excellent cinematography and an exceptionally good performance from child actor Zain Al Rafeea (as protagonist Zain), but is a mix of sincere, simple conflicts and laughably heavy-handed and unrealistic melodrama. Perhaps the best representation of this is a framing device where Zain literally takes his parents to court in an attempt to prevent them from having kids, where all the attendees are dumbfounded by the supposedly profound nature of his statements as if Frank Capra was brought on to tack on an ending to this screenplay. The events of the film are tragic, yes, but there isn't much in the way of context or theme to them, everything is just to provide another layer of struggle for our poor protagonist to contend with. Except juvenile prison, weirdly enough. It's sort of glossed over (like a lot in this film that probably should have been explored more), but once there Zain sort of gets taken in by an Artful Dodger-esque crowd without any sort of fanfare. It's Al Rafeea that really saves a lot of this film, delivering actual sincerity where Capernaum could have easily slid into being a very nicely framed arthouse melodrama alone. (2.5/5)

For this assignment I chose to write the film review on the movie we watched in class, Capernaum. This movie talks about the story of a Lebanese young boy who escapes from his careless parents. As the movie develops, it narrates how Zain, the young Lebanese boy, is able to survive on his own. He meets an Ethiopian refugee family, and as the mother gets caught, he took the role of a parent for the baby refugee, Yonas. Throughout the movie, viewers can see the horrible conditions these people live in and how mistreated and abused poor children are. This movie depicts many violations of human rights as it unfolds the conditions families in poverty live in. 

	Since the beginning of the film, viewers can start to notice the inhumane conditions characters in this movie live in. One of the many sisters Zayn has, Sahar, gets her period at the beginning of the movie. When Zayn realizes what will happen to Sahar when their parents notice that she got her period, he does everything in his power to help her hide it as much time as she can. He was trying to help his sister cover this since he knew once their parents notice it, she would be sent off to marry the shop owner that sent her free food once in a while. After his sister is sent off to marry the shop owner, Zayn vanishes to the streets, and this is when he finds the caring Ethiopian woman. He now starts taking care of the baby as his mother goes out to work. When the baby's mother gets sent off to prison, Zayn takes responsibility of taking care of baby Yonas. When Zayn realizes he can no longer take good care of baby Yonas, he gives him away to a human trafficker in exchange of him going off to another country and starting a new life. But for this, he needs his papers or some sort of identification. He decides to go back to his neglect household in order to get the documentation he needs to go off to another country. When he gets to his house, he realizes that his sister Sahar, is no longer alive. He gets carried away by his anger and stabs the shop owner, which gets him sent off to jail. In jail, he reunites with Yonas' mother, which makes her realize that Yonas got handed to the human trafficker. 

	This film portrays the reality of refugee children, poverty, and violated rights. It creates consciousness about the current refugee problem in Lebanon. There are around half a million refugee children in Lebanon. Currently, there are many organizations looking to solve this problem. They have successfully managed to open schools in order to offer free education for school-aged Syrian refugee children in Lebanon. They are now working on regain these projects since the coronavirus pandemic slowed the pace of their plans. The pandemic has interrupted the refugee children education in Lebanon and has affected the school openings. Humanitarian groups continue to work to provide better life conditions to these children. Even though some have managed to provide them with free education, many of them are still not able to attend classes because their families can not afford transportation. 

	In conclusion, the movie Capernaum depicts the effects violation of human rights have on refugee children that live in extreme poverty. Portraying these kids lives' challenges makes viewers realize the seriousness of the refugee problem in the world fast it is growing. Even though there are currently many donor organizations that work hard to minimize the refugee current problem, there is still a lot of work that can be done. In my opinion, producing a movie of the inhumane ways many people around the world live in, and how horrifying the effects are on their lives, is a great way to create awareness about the world's refugee crisis

This movie really opened my eyes. While showing very treacherous living and working conditions while following the life of a 12-year-old Zain, it also shows the very real situation happening in Lebanon. When Zain appears in court many times, we see that he is in fact the plaintiff and is wanting to sue his parents. When asked why, he responds "Because I was born." While living with his neglecting parents and many siblings, at times Zain has to choose between being a kid and working long shifts on the streets to support his large family. The actress and director Nadine Labaki says "How did we get to the point where we deprived a child of the most basic right, to close his eyes and sleep. This movie depicts child and human trafficking, the struggle and fear the undocumented population goes through every day, and the unknown struggle young children are put through in these slums. Zain even takes over the role of a caretaker when Rahil goes missing and he takes care of her daughter until he no longer can. 
The population of Lebanon, where the story is set, relies on commerce and trade; and Lebanon's foreign policy had been thoroughly influenced by Syria until 2005. In the movie, Zain is approached by a young Syrian girl who is selling boxes on the street. The girl told him about how she and her family received food, which was provided by a "food bank" for Syrian refugees. Zain pretends to be Syrian in order to get food and baby formula for him and the baby. Lebanon has many diplomatic relations with countries all over the world. Syrian refugees in Lebanon face many problems, including debt. Lebanon is already in a financial crisis, mainly due to the pandemic and the blast at the Port of Beirut. The poverty rates are rising every year. While the middle class is becoming poor, the poor are becoming extremely poor. The Lebanese government estimates around 1.5 million Syrian refugees as of 2020. Worsening economic and political instability has forced many people out of their countries and towards Lebanon. However, Lebanon is working with important international organizations such as Anera in order to help the refugees find places to live. 
In one scene, we see Rhail sitting with a queer couple - a transgender woman who sells snacks and a parking attendant who wears a spiderman costume and calls himself "cockroach man". The gender rights in Lebanon are not as progressive as they are in the United States, but the LGBTQ community is more free in  Lebanon than they are in other parts of the Arab world. There is a Penal Code that "prohibits having sexual relations that are "contradicting the laws of nature", which is punishable by up to a year in prison". In 2016, the Court of Appeals of Beirut stated that a transgender man is allowed to change his official identification after undergoing sex reassignment surgery. 
Capernaum does not have a specific theme besides exposing the reality of the lives of these people. We see corruption, racism, and moral dilemmas that Zain goes through, including the adults that are to blame for his poor way of life: his parents.
This is a neo-realistic drama and the way it is shot is almost documentary-like. It is very captivating and closely connects you to the characters to make you feel compassion towards them as they are suffering. 
I definitely recommend watching this movie. As I said at the beginning it is very eye opening and made me want to learn more about the current political situation of Lebanon and maybe find out how I can help.

Children should be attending school and not sent off around town to work for their parents, not only does making them work put them in a dangerous situation but it causes them to "grow up" quicker. 	The movie Capernaum has many examples of refugees and migration issues. The most prominent example would be when Tigest cannot afford to get her ID forged.
